Rural quality of life, meaning an individual's overall well-being, is both important and understudied. With one quarter of the total United States population living in rural communities located across 97 percent of American soil, understanding and evaluating rural well-being is essential in promoting rural economic growth and building a more sustainable future. This dissertation focuses on two measures of rural quality of life in Illinois: housing values and health care access. Through estimating housing price trends, evaluating policy impacts on rural hospital structures, and valuing rural hospitals as local amenities, rural quality of life in Illinois can be better understood. Housing price indexes capture trends in regional cost of living and convey a population's wealth. Using sales transaction data from the Illinois Department of Revenue, the first essay compares the median and Case-Shiller housing price capabilities to measure housing price appreciation and depreciation in rural, micro and metro Illinois from 2000 through 2009. During this time period, America experienced a housing boom and bust, with varied effects in metro, micro and rural areas. The Case-Shiller method captured the housing bubble in metro (excluding Chicago), micro and rural areas in Illinois. While micro and rural areas in Illinois did not experience a housing boom and bust as severe as that in Chicago, the Case-Shiller method corrects the assertion that rural America did not experience a housing bubble. xiii

The current trend of housing price indexes is dominated by repeat sales methods or some form of hedonic price method. There are a few other methods worth exploring in order to create the best rural housing price index for Illinois. The easiest methods for constructing housing price indexes are based on computing the mean or median price of properties that were sold during each time period. The distribution of prices in a mean housing index is sharply skewed, meaning that the mean price exceeds the median price. This is caused by fluctuations in sales volume among properties at extreme ends of the spectrum, which have a strong effect on the mean price but a muted effect on median price. In most cases, the median housing price index (HPI) is preferable, because it is not susceptible to being skewed by outliers. The median HPI has its share of shortcomings, however. It fails to control for changes in the quality or mix of properties whose prices were observed in each period. It is assumed that quality improves over time as new properties are constructed, older properties are demolished, and existing properties are renovated. Due to quality adjustments on price, using an average or median price index may or may not overstate the increase in price for a constant-quality property or for any existing property. The repeat sales model improves on the shortcomings of the median index, because it has the ability to control for constant quality. The repeat sales method is a ratio of two transaction prices for the same property in two time periods. If the characteristics of the house did not change between sales transactions, then only the following data is required: the time period in which each house transacted, the price, and the location or unique identifier of the property. The primary disadvantage of the repeat-sales model is that it can be estimated only on properties that sell at least twice during the study period. This results in a loss of 85 to 95 percent of the sales in the data set unless there is a large time interval. As the time interval increases, it becomes more challenging to maintain the constant quality assumption.

The median index means that 50 percent of the houses are above this price and 50 percent of the houses fall below this price. Any outliers in the data set will not be able to skew the index as much as the mean housing price index. One drawback of using the median index over time is that the mix of houses in the sample may change. If in one year more high priced houses sell, the median will be high. If the next year sees more low priced houses sold, the median will be low. In this case, the median reflects the mix of houses that sold rather than drop in housing values.

Thus, demographic characteristics and economic characteristics of the market area often determine the number of hospital beds, the number of staff, and the type of hospital ownership are elements of hospital structure. In addition, government intervenes in hospital markets, due to their im-perfectly competitive nature. When a rural hospital closes, the entire community is affected. Longo and Chase (1984) find that due to "the social, economic and political significance of most hospitals, closure usually has profound implications in terms of employment, access and availability to health care services, and even the overall economic stability of an area." The elderly, disabled, uninsured, and individuals needing emergent care are the most affected. While CAHs are somewhat limited in the scope of their services, they do provide necessary basic care for those most in need in rural communities, especially elderly residents. The most important health benefit of having a hospital in a rural community is evident in time-sensitive medical care, such as in the cases of an acute myocardial infarction, major car accident, or farm accident. (Buchmueller et al., 2006) In accidents and heart attacks, the chances of survival or full recovery rely on receiving immediate medical attention. For rural elderly residents, having a hospital in their rural communities reduces the travel time. In most rural communities, a lack of public transportation leaves many residents without cars relying on others to transport them to and from the hospital.

section_title: Supply and Demand Sides of Hospitals
text: Government policy is only one determinant of changes to the structure of the hospital industry. There are other factors that need to be examined to understand the forces affecting the structure of the hospital industry. According to Longo and Chase (1984), hospital structure depends on a number of factors that stem from hospital supply and demand. Figure 3 focuses on the hospital in the center of the diagram. The hospital structure is made up of the number of beds, the number of staff, nurses, and doctors, the extent of services offered, and the ownership. The number of beds in a hospital is a basic indicator of the number of services. As the number of beds increases, so do the number of services. The hospital needs doctors, nurses and staff in order to provide patient services. Doctors and nurses need the hospital for wages and for the use of technologies and facilities housed in the hospital. The supply of hospital services depends on the doctors, nurses, and staff, in addition to the hospital competition in the area. Competition can be a good thing, because it can lower costs to the patient and increase efficiencies by decreasing the number of unused beds and reducing staff. Competition can also promote differentiation, such that one hospital could offer different services than another nearby hospital. Competition can also lead to hospital closings. Competition can be measured in terms of hospital market share (number of hospital beds as percent of total in market area), the number of hospitals in an area, and the distance to another hospital. There are several environmental factors that impact the demand side of hospital services. Patients demand health services from the hospital. In rural areas, patients typically use the hospital for primary care as well as emergent care services. Environmental influences on de-mand include: the total population in the area, the change in the total population, the change in total population above 65, per capita income, percent of the population living in poverty, and the unemployment rate. If the population is low near the hospital, the hospital will struggle. If the population near the hospital decreases over time, the hospital will struggle. Increases in poverty, unemployment, and the number of elderly and disabled in a community have negative financial impacts on the hospital. Government policies impact the hospital both directly and indirectly. Government policies, such as CAH, restrict bed size. Medicare has certain staffing requirements, thus increasing a hospital's overhead. Government policies also impact hospital demand through the use of Medicare and Medicaid. In Table V the types of hospital ownership in Illinois are given by classification in 1998. The types of hospital ownership are: government, non-profit religious affiliated, non-profit other, and private for-profit. Decisions about hospital structure made by the hospital leadership depend on the type of ownership. Decisions to exit the hospital market also depend on the hospital ownership. Capps et al. (2010) find that for-profit hospitals exit the market when their marginal cost exceeds marginal revenue, which is consistent with economic theory. text: Cox regression models are sometimes referred to as proportional hazard models, duration models, or survival models with the main purpose of determining the time it takes before an event occurs. Cox regressions are semi-parametric and are used to examine the effect of a set of covariates on the hazard rate, which in this paper is the risk of closure. The purpose of using a Cox regression is to determine if CAH status slowed the closure rate of hospitals in Illinois from 1997 through 2007. The dependent variable is called duration, which is a combination variable of the time to an event (hospital closure) and whether the event occurred or was censored (the end of the study). Duration is assumed to follow the density function f (t). The cumulative distribution function, F(t), or probability that the duration time will be less than t, is denoted in Equation 3.1. The survival function is the probability that the duration will be at least t (Equation 3.2). The hazard rate is the probability that the event will happen at time t given that the individual is at risk at time t. The hazard rate is given in Equation 3.3. The hazard rate in the Cox proportional hazard model is defined in Equation 3.4.

This section describes the semilogarithmic hedonic housing price equation, as described by . In Equation 4.1, Hedonic prices stem from the works of Rosen (1974) and Roback (1982). In the models presented in this paper, the ln P i is the logarithm of the price of property i. The vector of X i variables include: natural logarithm of building area, natural logarithm of land area, natural logarithm of the age of the structure, Other X i variables are bedrooms, bathrooms, garage, central air conditioning, percent of vacant homes, percent African Americans, and percent Hispanic. The δ i represents distance variables, such as: natural logarithm of the distance to the high school, natural logarithm of the distance to the county seat, natural logarithm of the distance to the nearest high school. The ε term is the error term. There are four hedonic models for each county. The first model is a simple semi-logarithmic hedonic model using the natural logarithm of price and the natural logs of the following: the square feet of the housing structure, the land square feet, age of the structure. Included in the simple model (model 1) are also discrete variables: number of bedrooms, number of bathrooms, presence of a garage, and central air conditioning. The second model includes the variables from the simple model adding only the natural logarithm of distance from the house to the hospital. The third model builds on the second by adding the natural logarithm of the distance to the county seat and neighborhood characteristics at the census tract level: percent black or African American, percent Hispanic, and percent vacant homes. The fourth model adds the final amenity variable: distance to the nearest high school. The distance to the county seat is added to the models, because there was concern that the distance to the hospital variable was a proxy for the distance to the large town.
